document_title: Postpartum dyshidrosis: Causes, signs, treatment and prevention
subsection_content:
During the first few days after giving birth, the body will expel a large amount of blood, bright red and similar to menstruation, accompanied by small blood clots. 10 days after birth, the lochia gradually dilutes, mainly containing white blood cells and cells from the uterine lining.
In the following days, the lochia will gradually decrease before completely disappearing after 2-4 weeks. In some cases, vaginal discharge continues for the next few weeks, up to 45 days after birth.
The above process takes place in pregnant women with normal vaginal discharge. But if you find yourself experiencing the following unusual symptoms, think about the phenomenon of obstetric and gynecological blockage:
The lochia flows very little and has a foul smell due to infection; Tightness in the lower abdomen, sometimes with dull pain; There is a hard lump in the abdomen, clearly felt when touched; Body temperature increases; Cervix is ​​closed, pain when pressing the bottom of the uterus
